Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The Department of Justice announced that an $80 million False Claims Act judgment was entered against BNP Paribas for submitting false claims for payment guarantees issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order instituting and simultaneously settling charges against BNP Paribas Securities Corp. for violating the CFTC's Regulations governing concentration limits applicable to the investment of segregated commodity customer funds.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced that BNP Paribas Commodity Futures, Ltd. would pay a $25,000 civil monetary penalty to settle charges that it failed to provide to the CFTC timely and accurate account information for a reportable large trader account, as required by CFTC regulations.

The Board levied the fine after finding deficiencies in BNP Paribas's oversight of, and internal controls over, FX traders who buy and sell U.S. dollars and foreign currencies for the firm's own accounts and for customers. The Board said the firm failed to detect and address that its traders used electronic chatrooms to communicate with competitors about their trading positions.

BNP Paribas S.A.  was sentenced for conspiring to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and the Trading with the Enemy Act by processing billions of dollars of transactions through the U.S. financial system on behalf of Sudanese, Iranian and Cuban entities subject to U.S. economic sanctions. BNPP was sentenced to a five-year term of probation, and ordered to forfeit $8,833,600,000 to the United States and to pay a $140,000,000 fine. The penalty also covered cases brought by the Office of Foreign Assets Control and the Federal Reserve.
BNP Paribas USA Inc., a subsidiary of BNP Paribas S.A., pleaded guilty to participating in a price-fixing conspiracy in the foreign currency exchange (FX) market.

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against BNP Paribas Securities Corp. for attempted manipulation of the ISDAFIX benchmark by requiring the company to pay a $90 million civil monetary penalty.

BNP Paribas pleaded guilty and was ordered to pay $2.2 billion  to the Manhattan District Attorney's Office and the City of New York in connection with charges that it violated New York State law by conspiring to and falsifying the records of New York financial institutions, allowing clients to avoid U.S. economic sanctions meant to prohibit transactions with Sudanese, Iranian and Cuban entities. This and another $2.2 billion penalty paid directly to the state were part of a larger $8.8 billion settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bnp-paribas-sa
Notes: The New York City amount is clarified in the attached settlement document.

Description: The New York State Department of Financial Services announced that BNP Paribas would pay a penalty of $2.24 billion tas part of the resolution of allegations that it engaged in a scheme to concealed more than $190 billion in transactions between 2002 and 2012 for clients subject to U.S. sanctions, including Sudan, Iran, and Cuba. The penalty was part of a larger $8.8 billion settlement that also included a federal criminal case; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bnp-paribas-sa
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: BNP Paribas S.A. and its New York branch agreed to pay a $350 million fine as part of a consent order entered into with the New York State Department of Financial Services for violations of New York banking law arising out of the bank's global foreign-exchange business.  The violations were said to have included deficiencies in the bank's oversight that allowed nearly unfettered misconduct by more than a dozen BNPP traders and salespeople.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: BNP Paribas Securities Corp. and BNP Paribas Prime Brokerage, Inc.
Description: FINRA fined BNP Paribas Securities Corp. and BNP Paribas Prime Brokerage, Inc. $15 million for anti-money laundering program and supervisory failures involving penny stock deposits and resales, and wire transfers, that spanned four years.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.
